content.description: Start the climb under a round/overhanging hard start that feels like a boulder problem (crux) and around 10 feet up, place your first pro (big cam). Keep in mind that the ground is very steep at the start. If you fall at that point expect an akward fall, a good spotter will be a good confidence boost. You then get to a plateau and it goes on into an easy corner through some vegetation to a belay (I don't remember if its bolted or not but there is a belay). Approximately in the middle of the area where the rock curves, hence the name Buttocks Les Fesses #5 cam for the first placement, a #4 can protect but be careful with your placement then it's a regular rack.

départ sur le bloc dans le face. grimper tout droite et aller sur la droite dans le dièdre pour traverser sous le toit vers la gauche. La fin est le crux a la dernière bolt 

sport bolt

Finger crack starting on the right side of the vertical wall without base (roof).  Join the 2 glue-ins after the big horizontal crack.

Fissure à doigts débutant à la droite du mur vertical sans base (toit).  Rejoindre les 2 scellements après la grosse fissure horizontale.



Tougher than it looks! Small cams for the crack and #.75 for the horizontal.

Plus corsée que s'en a l'air! Petites cams pour la fissure et #.75 pour l'horizontale.

Bolted arete on the left of Popeye angled roof.

Arrête boltée à gauche du surplomb en angle de Popeye.


Bolts

Follow the bolts to get on the arête (crux). One or two natural protections before topping out as the difficulty eases.



Last route on the extreme left of the cliff.

4 bolts, 0.4 at the horizontal, glue-ins to rap.

An old school 5.8 crack with friction feet and the occasional shallow toe jam which is tricky to climb and to protect.

Start by bridging against the left side of the adjacent chimney to reach the beginning of the right-slanting finger crack.



Right-slanting finger crack on the face just right of a dirty chimney.


Single rack. First pro is tips. Totems and offsets are great. Some finger size nuts.

jump start (stick clip the first) and go fin the crux in the face 

sport

Obvious dihedral going all the way up while passing 2 large slabs. It's very dirty and may have some loose rocks. More traffic would suit it as it would be a nice route to learn trad on. Dièdre évident qui passe par deux dalles. La voie est très sale et quelques roches peuvent êtres en position précaire. Elle mérite d'être nettoyée et voir plus de gens dessus. Ça serait une belle voie d'apprentissage pour le trad. 2nd route on the wall starting from climber's right.

2e voie du mur en partant à la droite du grimpeur SLCDs (up to number 3), long runners.

Des coinceurs mécaniques (jusqu'à un numéro 3) et de longues déguaines.

climbs.name: Gumby
climbs.fa: paul laperriere 1996 et yann gauthier 2019 nouvelle fin

content.description:
Départ évident sur le gros bloc face à la belle fissure. La voie était auparavant mixe et finissait au relais de la voie à sa gauche. En 2019 la voie était salle et presque jamais faite, la protection était douteuse et peu sécuritaire. Yann et Alex on nettoyer le voie et l'on rééquipée, un relais indépendant a été ajouté directe au dessus du toit. Le crux est vraiment intéressant au milieux de la voie. Je recommandes cette voie la. 

Départ sur le bloc en face de la craque. 
sport

Un départ aisé vous mènera à un dièdre fissuré. Grimper ce dernier et traversez à droite pour atteindre les plaquettes. Sortir tout droit dans les petits toits.  Le relais se trouve plus haut sur la dalle.

Un départ aisé vous mènera à un dièdre fissuré. Grimper ce dernier et traversez à droite pour atteindre les plaquettes. Sortir tout droit dans les petits toits.  Le relais se trouve plus haut sur la dalle.



The vertical corner left of the generally wet streak.

Le coin vertical à gauche de la traînée généralement humide.


Small and medium cams for the start.

Mécaniques petits et moyens pour le départ.

Complete right of Les Fesses area. Its a long slab of 40 meters. The route is a little dirty, especially the start. Several fun sequences. 2 sections of approximately 5 meters where runout. The rest was good.

I used double ropes as the route is at least 40 meters and there does not seem to be a way to walk down from the top.

climbs.name: Le petit frisson du Pit Bull

content.description:
Variation that climbs the start of the route "Petit Frisson" and ends in the crack of "Pit Bull". It is the logical continuation of the boulder problem on the left corner of this wall. Short but touching!

Variante qui grimpe le départ de la voie ''Petit Frisson'' et qui se termine dans la fissure de ''Pit Bull''. C'est la suite logique du problème de bloc du coin gauche de ce mur. Court mais touchant! 



Start on the top of the block to the left of the vertical wall without base (roof). Good holds will lead you to the superb crux.

Départ sur le dessus du bloc à gauche du mur vertical sans base (toit). De bonnes prises vous mèneront au superbe crux.


A good small cam (red C3) at the beginning of the traverse protects the crux.

Un bon petit coinceur mécanique au début de la traverse (C3 rouge) protège le crux.

Up the slab at the nose of Les Fesses. Pass to the left of the bloc to the flat section above. Traverse the flat section containing one piton. Up a diagonal right crack to the top. Route is convoluted and ambiance is airy in the second half. I used double ropes. Parts of this route that cannot be seen from the start take longer to dry after rain than most other routes. Also the start and several sections are a little dirty. Good, has one piton in crack above start and one piton in middle flat section.

Did not use anything above 2 inches. Bring long slings. Rope drag may be an issue.

Start under the pointy roof, follow the slanted finger/hand crack that goes to the left. The crux starts once your head is close to the roof just before a short offwidth. Then you go over a block to a vertical hand crack that is shared with Popeye. It takes you to a bolted anchor for belay. 
  
 Make sure the second can take all the gear out!

On the left end
Standard rack with a focus on finger/hand size protection and a Camalot #3 and #4. Placements are excellent, only the short offwidth crack is tricky to protect so that the rope doesn't mess with your gear, long runners are useful for that part.

Start into a hand crack that is usually wet and mossy and climb up to a block, then follow a left slanted crack that is shared under the roof with  Olive that takes you to a bolted anchor.

Left of Olive (see photo)
Standard rack with a focus on hand size gear and maybe a Camalot #3 and #4 cam

Up the techy face to an easy section before passing the roof on its left (crux).

Topo has it at 11a but it's definitely not that hard.



Second line of bolts, extreme left of the cliff.

3 bolts, finger size at the rest, .3 after the roof, glue-ins for rappel.

la craque évidente juste a droite de trois quart putain. La cote du livre guide est 5.10d mais bouche trou qui est 5.11d juste a droite partage la meme fin et pour nous le crux se trouve être en haut pour les deux voie..... Donc la cote devrait sensiblement être la même. Étrange a vous de juger. 

mixe

this one is really good, bouldering start goes to a face crux.... dont blow the last move :)

Une classique a faire, le début est très bloc pour aller chercher un deuxième crux dans la face très délicate, le dernier mouvement semble donner de la difficulté à plusieurs, il faut tenir le slope de la sortie mains droite pour aller chercher une bonen prise plus loins. Un bijoux caché de Val-david selon moi. Plusieurs prises de sont brisés depuis l’ouverture. La cote est à confirmé mais elle ne va pas en descendant 

all sport

Yorkshire is in between Pitt Bull and Caniche. They all shares the same start, but Yorkshire climbs the flared and closed crack between the two line.

2 pre-placed RPs.


Single Rack #0.1 to #2, one BD micro stopper #6 and one BD stopper #1

The area is in a small valley in the middle of the park between La Bleue and Mont-King. It has a really nice vibe but it's probably one of the places at Val-David that needs more time to dry and would be comparable to La Bleu in that matter. The left side is often in the shade and the right side gets sunlight pretty much all day. Not crowded and very quiet. 
  
 It's mostly trad climbs with a range from 5.7 to 5.11D and very few mixed and sport routes. Toproping is not recommended here since there is no path to the top and a lot of routes go too much sideways. The guide book indicates there are 30 routes. It also felt pretty sandbagged....even for Val-David grades! 
  
 I really liked this place so I'am putting up what I've climbed to date with the photos I have. Feel free to add routes and more information.
